Data Muses

Gaurav Godhwani

Should Schools Be Closed? Learning from Schooloscope, an OpenData post-mortem

27 Oct 2014

Schooloscope was the brainchild of Berg London, a multitalented design studio. Launched in May 2010, the site took performance survey data (Ofsted) about state-run primary and secondary schools and layered it on a map to visualise proximity, size, performance, trends and a whole variety of other parameters. Mushon Zer-Aviv a designer, educator and media activist based in NYC says in his detailed case study, "Since I first laid my cursor on Schooloscope.com it intrigued me as an exceptional case in the world of open data and information design. The chain of events that led to the site’s termination is an important story, which I believe should be chronicled and told."

How Nations Fare in PhDs by Sex [Interactive]

16 Sep 2014

In this interactive chart Scientific American assembles data collected by the National Science Foundation, tracing the gender gap at the doctoral level for 56 nations. The situation in individual countries varies widely, but as the numbers make clear, there are interesting exceptions to the global trend. Explore in detail here.

DC KIDS COUNT Data Tool [Interactive]

24 Jun 2014

“Children are deeply affected, in all aspects of their lives, by the conditions in their immediate surroundings,” writes HyeSook Chung, Executive Director of DC Action for Children. “How does US capital – one of the most affluent, educated and wealthy cities in the nation – have one of the worst child poverty rates?” DC Action for Children and DataKind came up with DC KIDS COUNT Data Tool 2.0 to map and analyze neighborhood-level needs, progress, and outcomes and drive these insights allow to shape data driven policy solutions. Read more about this here.

More than 400,000 Stolen Years: An Examination of U.S. Gun Murders

03 Nov 2013

Using data from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Uniform Crime Report and the World Health Organization’s UNSD Demographic Statistics, this data exploration tool visualizes the gun murders that took place in 2010, the most recent year for which data is available. Periscopic discuss the background information about this project.

Google I/O 2013 - Google Maps + HTML5 + Spatial Data Visualization: A Love Story

23 May 2013

Much if not most of the world's data has a geographic component. Data visualizations with a geographic component are some of the most popular on the web. This session will explore the principles of data visualization and how you can use HTML5 - particularly WebGL - to supplement Google Maps visualizations., Brendan Kenny works at Google as an engineer with the Maps Developer Relations team and mostly works with JavaScript APIs.
